note_models.name: Basic

fields: The standard AAs have the same general structure except what?
Proline (ring structure)
What is the physiological pH?
What is the name of the property in which an AA can behave as an acid or a base?
Amphoteric property
At physiologic pH, the carboxyl group is __ and the amino group is __
dissociated (forms negative ion), protonated
Neutral molecules that bear an equal number of positive and negative charges simultaneously are called?
Zwitterions
Name the nonpolar amino acids
Leucine, Isoleucine, Valine, Alanine, Methionine, Glycine, Proline, Phenylalanine, Tryptophan
AAs with nonpolar side chains are __ and have an __ or __ __ property
Hydrophobic, Lipid like
Cell membranes are hydrophilic or hydrophobic environments?
hydrophobic
Due to its rigid ring structure, proline interrrupts what in globular proteins?
the a-helices
In sickle cell anemia, what is substituted for what and in what subunit?
In hemoglobin A, the polar glutamate is substituted for nonpolar valine at the 6th position from the n terminus in the b-subunits
What are the uncharged polar amino acids?
Serine, Threonine, tyrosine, asparagine, glutamine, cysteine
Polar uncharged AAs are hydrophilic and can participate in what kind of bonding?
Hydrogen bonding
Hydroxyl groups serve as attachment sites for what groups?
Phosphate groups
Amide and hydroxyl groups serve as attachment sites for what in glycoproteins?
oligosaccharide chains
Sulfhydryl groups are inportant components of what in enzymes?
Active site
What are the acidic amino acids?
Aspartate and glutamate
Are acidic AAs proton donors or acceptors?
Donors
What are the basic amino acids?
Histidine, Arginine, Lysine
Basic AAs are proton acceptors or donors?
Acceptors
Which basic AA is only weakly basic?
Histidine because it is only partially ionized at physiologic pH
What are the essential AAs?
Phenylalanine, Valine, Threonine, Tryptophan, Isoleucine, Methionine, Histidine, Arginine (only in infants), Leucine, Lysine
What is the one AA that is not chiral and doesn't have a D and L form?
Glycine
What are the two forms of chiral molecules called?
Enantiomers or optical isomers
D enantiomers rotate light in which direction?
Right (+), clockwise
L enantiomers rotate light in which direction?
Left (-), counterclockwise
All AAs found in proteins are in what configuration?
L
AAs in aqueous solution contain weakly acidic __ groups and weakly basic __ groups
Carboxyl, amino
What is the Bronsted-Lowry Theory?
It states that Acids are proton donors and bases are proton acceptors
What is the relationship between the dissociation constant (Ka) and Acid stregnth?
The larger the Ka, the stronger the acid and vice versa
What does the dissociation constant equal? (equation)
Ka = ([H+] [A-]) / [HA] (concentration of products over reactants)
What is the relationship between Ka, pKa, and acid strength?
The Larger the Ka, the smaller the pKa, the stronger the acid and vice versa
What is pKa (equation?)
pKa = -log Ka
What is the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation for pH?
pH = pKa + log [A-] / [HA]
What is pH (equation in terms of [H+]?)
pH = -log [H]
When the concentration of products is greater than concentration of reactants, the pH is __ than the pKa
Greater, because the log of greater than 1 is positive. This also means the AA is deprotonated (more product than reactant)
What constitutes a good buffer?
A mixture of weak acid and its conjugate base in close cencentration with each other
What is the buffer range?
+/- 1 pH unit of the acid's pKa value. So if pKa of acid is 5, the buffer pH should be within 5 or 7
What is a buffer?
A solution that resists change in pH following addition of an acid or base
T/F: AAs have more than one pKa
True
pKa of carboxylic group is __ than pKa of amino group
Lower (Carboxylic = 9.1, amino group = 2.3)
What is the isoelectric point?
The pI is the average of the pKas. It is the pH at which a molecule possesses no net charge. There are equal amounts of form 1 and 3
What is the primary structure of a protein?
The AA sequence
What is the secondary structure of a protein?
The coiling and folding of polypeptide chain
What is the tertiary structure of a protein?
The 3D shape of the polypeptide caused by weak interactions between R groups and fluid environment
What is the quaternary structure of a protein?
The 3D structure formed by interactions of more than one polypeptide chain
Peptide bonds are what kind of bonds?
Covalent
How are peptide bonds hydrolyzed nonenzymatically?
Through prolonged exposure to strong acid or base at high temp
What is the name of the enzymes that hydrolyze peptide bonds?
Peptidases/proteases
What are the two types of peptidases?
Exo and endo. Exo cuts at ends and endo cuts within protein
AA sequences are read from what end to what end?
N terminus to C terminus
Each component AA in a polypeptide is called a what?
Residue
How do you name polypeptides?
The AA residues have their suffixes changed to -yl with exception of C terminal AA.
The peptide bond is generally in trans or cis?
Trans so that the R groups do not have steric hinderance
What are the stop codons?
UAA, UAG, UGA
What amino acid codes for the start codon?
Methionine (AUG)
What kind of bonds are involved in the secondary structure of proteins?
Hydrogen bonds between the C=O and N-H groups between AAs
In an a-helix, the sides chains extend inward or outward?
Outward to avoid steric hinderance
How many AAs per turn of a-helix?
What AA disrupts a-helices?
Proline, because it is not geometrically compatible with right hand spiral of helix
What proteins are alpha helical?
Keratins and myoglobins
2 or more segments of polypeptide chains lined up side by side is called
b-sheet
What are the individual segments of b-sheets called?
b-strands
What are the two forms of b-sheets?
parallel and antiparallel
What are the four ways tertiary structure is held together?
H bonds, disulfide bonds, ionic interactions, hydrophobic interactions
What specialized group of proteins are required for proper folding of proteins?
Chaperones
What are the three steps of protein folding?
Formation of secondary structures, formation of domains, formation of final protein monomer
Denaturation results in unfolding of which structures?
secondary and tertiary. Not accompanied by hydrolysis of peptide bonds
What are the six denaturing agents?
Heat, organic solvents, mechanical mixing, strong acids or bases, detergents, ions of heavy metals
T/F: Denaturation may or may not be reversible
True
Quaternary structure is held together by what interactions?
Non covalent: H bonds, hydrophobic, ionic
What are the two ways quaternary structures can function?
Independently or cooperatively
What are isoforms?
Proteins that perform the same function but have different primary structures
What are isozymes?
Protein isoforms that function as enzymes
Misfolded proteins are tagged by what?
Ubiquitin
What two diseases can result from protein misfolding?
amyloid and prion
The accumulation of insoluble, spontaneously agggregating proteins is called what?
amyloids consisting of b-pleated sheets
What are some amyloid diseases?
Alzheimer's and Parkinsons
Prions form aggregates of what?
Fibrils
Prions cause what?
Transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSE) such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, Scrapie, Bovine spongform encephalopathy
Resistance to degradation is caused by what?
Prions (infectious)- can cause non infectious to becoe infectious
Name the two globular proteins
Hemoglobin, myoglobin
the prosthetic group heme reversibly binds
Oxygen
Myoglobin's two functions
oxygen reservoir, oxygen carrier that increases rate of transport of O2
Myoglobin consists of how many polypeptide chains?
one
What gives tissues their characteristic red color?
Myoglobin
Hemoglobin carries what from tissues to lungs
H+ and CO2
Lots of myoglobin in the blood allows what?
To hold breath for a long time
Sickle cell affects which chains of hemoglobin?
both beta chains
How many forms do hemoglobin have?
Two. Relaxed and deoxygenated
The O2 dissociation curve of hemoglobin is what shape?
sigmoidal
Which globular protein has higher affinity for oxygen?
myoglobin
What allows hemoglobin to bind better as more O2 is present?
Cooperative binding
Myoglobin gives up O2 only when
Muscle cell O2 is very low, because myoglobin has high affinity for O2, allowing O2 to enter muscles from blood
What is the Bohr effect?
Change in O2 binding affinity of Hb due to other ligands binding Hb
What are the ligands that bind Hb for the Bohr effect?
H+, 2,3- bisphophoglycerate, CO2. These stabilize the taut state and help Hb let go of oxygen
Decrease in pH (H+), 2,3-bis, and CO2 results in __ oxygen affinity
Decreased
CO causes Hb to shift to what state?
Relaxed
Hemoglobinopathies are genetic disorders caused by the production of
Structurally abnormal Hb molecule, insufficient quantities of normal Hb, or both
Name the hemoglobinopathies
Sickle cell anemia, Hemoglobin C disease (glutamate is substituted with lysine, Hemoglobin SC disease (both Hb S and Hb C), Thallassemia syndromes (decreased production of normal hemoglobin)
Fibrous proteins typically contain what structural elements?
secondary
Fibrous proteins are mostly what kind of proteins?
Structural
Examples of fibrous proteins
Collagen, Elastin, a-keratin, silk fibroin
Collagen is composed of how many polypeptide helices?
What type of collagen is found in teeth?
Type 1
AA composition of collagen includes?
Glycine, proline and 4-hydroxyproline, 3-hydroxyproline and 5-hydroxylysine
Steps of collagen synthesis

Transcription- nucleus
Translation- outside
Hydroxylation of proline and lysine
Glycoslyation
Procollagen- inside membrane
Tropocollagen formed outside membrane
collagen
Collagen is formed by multiple what?
tropocollagen
What diseases result from Collagen synthesis defects?
EDS (Ehlers danlos syndrome- stretchy skin and loose joints), and OI (Osteogenesis imperfecta- bones easily bend and fracture)
Elastin fibers are found where?
Lungs, walls of large arteries, elastic ligaments
Keratin is composed of what kind of polypeptides?
a-helical
RNAs with catalytic activity are called what?
ribozymes
What are the six enzyme classes?
Oxidoreductase, transferase, hydrolase, lyase, isomerase, ligase
Synthetase requires what to work?
ATP
Synthase does not require __
ATP
Phosphatase removes what group?
Phosphate
Phosphorylase uses inorganic phosphate to do what?
Break bond
This enzyme adds phosphate group from a high energy molecule such as ATP
This enzyme removes electrons and does not add oxygen atoms to substrate
Oxidase
This enzyme oxidizes substrate by transferring oxygen atoms to it
Oxygenase
What are the two ways to oxidize something?
Add oxygen or remove electrons
Enzymes are how many times faster than uncatalyzed rxns?
An enzyme with its nonprotein component is called what?
Holoenzyme
An enzyme without its nonprotein component is called what?
Apoenzyme
A nonprotein moeity that is primarily inorganic and sometimes organic is
A cofactor
A nonprotein moeity that is a small organic molecule is a
Coenzyme
Coenzymes that are permanently associated with the enzyme are called
Prosthetic group
Coenzymes that only transiently associate with the enzyme are called
Cosubstrates
Enzymes that change their conformation when bound by an effector at a site other than the active site are called
Allosteric Enzyme
Reaction velocity is affected by what three factors?
Substrate concentration, temperature, pH
What is the Michaelis Menten equation?
Vo = (Vmax[S] / Km + [S])
The higher the Km, the __ the affinity
Lower
When [S] is much less than Km, the reaction is in __ order
First
When [S] is greater than Km, the reaction is in __ order
Zero order. V is constant and independent of [S]
A lineweaver burk plot allows one to see what?
A straight line for 1/Vo vs. 1/[S]
In a lineweaver burk plot, the x axis is equal to
-1/Km
In a lineweaver burk plot, the y axis is equal to
1/Vmax
Reversible inhibitors bind to enzymes through __ bonds and irreversible ones bind to enzymes through __ bonds
noncovalent, covalent
Two types of reversible inhibitors include?
Competitive and noncompetitive
A noncompetitive inhibitor binds at what sites?
Binds E or ES at site different from active site
b-lactam antibiotics suchas penicillin and amoxicillin act to do what?
inhibit enzymes involved in bacterial cell wall synthesis
What is it called when the substrate itself serves as an effector?
homotropic effector
Effectors that are different from the substrate are called what?
Heterotropic effectors
Covalent modification of enzymes are done through what method?
Most frequently by addition or removal of phosphate groups from serine, threonine, or tyrosine residues
Phosphorylation reactions are catalyzed by a family of enzymes called?
Protein kinases
Dephosphorylation reactions are catalyzed by a family of enzymes called?
Phosphoprotein phosphatases
Enzymes regulate the amount of enzyme synthesis through what two methods?
Induction and repression
What is energy?
The ability to do work
What study predicts if a process is possible?
Bioenergetics
What are the three factos of bioenergetics?
Enthaly, entropy, and Free energy.
What value is G when a process is in equilibrium?
The standard free energy change of 2 consecutive reactions are additive or subtractive?
Additive
What is the value of the standard free energy of hydrolysis of ATP?
-7.3kcal/mol
What is the end product of glycolysis?
Pyruvate
What is the end product(s) of the TCA/Krebs cycle?
NADH and FADH2
What is oxidative phosphorylation
The process by which energy from the ETC is used to convert ADP to ATP
As electrons are passed down ETC, they lose energy. Where does this energy go?
Ancillary rxns such as Ca 2+ transport into mitochondria, and also to generate heat!
Give an example of substrate level phosphorylation
Oxidative phosphorylation
Where does glycolysis occur?
In the cytosol
Where does the TCA occur?
In the mitochondria
Where does the ETC occur?
In the inner membrane of mitochondria
Is the inner membrane of the mitochondria permeable or impermeable to small ions?
Impermeable
The mitochondria matrix contains what?
NAD+, FAD+, ADP, Pi
How many protein complexes are in the ETC?
Which protein complex in ETC uses NADH?
Complex 1
Which protein complex in ETC uses FADH2?
Complex 2
In which protein complex does ATP synthesis occur?
Complex 5
How many H atoms can complex 1 of ETC accept?
Another name for coenzyme Q is?
Ubiquinone
Where is oxygen reduced to water in ETC?
Complex 4
O2 is reduced to water due to the association of what three things?
Transported electrons, O2, and free protons
Reactive oxygen species result due to what?
Incomplete reduction of oxygen to water
What enzymes are cellular defenses against ROS?
superoxide dismutase, catalase, and glutathione peroxidase
What determines direction of electron flow in the ETC?
Standard reduction potential
Electrons flow from what standard reduction potential to what?
Negative to positive
NADH generates how much ATP?
FADH2 produces how much ATP?
What is the chemiosmotic hypothesis?
It explains how the free energy generated by the electrons thorugh the ETC is used to produce ATP
What drives the proton gradient?
The electrons that are passed along the complexes attract the protons through the complexes
Which complexes in the ETC allow protons to be pumped?
What are the two outcomes of the proton gradient?
There is an electrical and pH gradient. More positive in intramembrane space and lower pH in intermembrane space
How many protons does NADH force through the complexes?
10. 4 thorugh complex 1, 4 through complex 3, and 2 through complex 4
How many protons are needed to make 1 ATP?
Why is it that FADH2 only produces 1.5 ATP?
Because FADH2 uses complex 2, and complex 2 doesn't span the membrane, so no protons come through
When protons reenter the matrix through the Fo domain of complex 5, what happens?
Fo rotates, the pH and electrical gradients are dissipated
The rotation of Fo causes what?
Conformation change in F1 domain that converts ADP + Pi to ATP
What are uncoupling proteins?
They increase the permeability of the inner mitochondrial membrane, so that protons reenter the matrix without the energy spent on making ATP. Instead, heat is formed
Energy released as heat is referred to as?
nonshivering thermogenesis
Examples of nonshivering thermogenesis?
Thermogenin in brown fat, dinitrophenol (synthetic chemical), and high dose aspirin
What are the two types of carbs?
Aldoses and ketoses
What are isomers?
compound with the same chemical formula but different structure
What are epimers?
isomers that differ in configuration around only one specific carbon atom (with exception of the carbonyl carbon)
What are enantiomers?
isomers that are mirror images of each other
Most sugars are in what form?
D
What are racemases
Enzymes that convert D and L isomers
Name of 6 membered ring consisting of 5 carbon and 1 oxygen?
Pyranose
Name of 5 membered ring with 4 carbons and 1 oxygen?
Furanose
Cyclization results in what happening to the carbonyl carbon?
It becomes a new chiral center and is called the anomeric carbon
In a Fisher projection, the a anomeric hydroxyl group occurs on which side?
Right
In a Haworth projection the a anomeric hydroxyl occurs on which side?
Bottom/ opposite of CH2OH
T/F: All monosaccharides are reducing sugars
True
What happens if the hydroxyl group on the anomeric carbon of cyclized sugar is not linked to another compound?
It reverts back to aldehyde form and becomes a reducing sugar
What happens when a reducing sugar is mixed with a chromogenic agent?
The reagent is reduced and the aldehyde group becomes oxidized to a carboxyl group
What are glycosidic bonds formed by?
glycosyltransferases
T/F: Carbs can only be attached by glycosidic bonds to other carbs
false. Can bond to purine and pyrimidine bases, aromatic rings, proteins, and lipids
These enzymes hydrolyze glycosidic bonds
Glycosidases
Name the monosaccharides
Glucose, galactose, fructose
What are the two forms of starch?
Amylose (straight chain) and amylopectin (branched)
Amylase acts in the mouth to randomly break what kind of bonds?
Why are humans not able to digest cellulose?
Because of the b 1-4 bonds, which humans do not have the enzymes to break
Why does amylase activity halt in the stomach?
Because the high acidity inactivates salivary amylase
How is salivary amylase reactivated after the stomach?
The acidic stomach contents reach the small intestine, where they are neutralized by bicarbonate secreted by pancreas
Where does digestion of carbs end?
Small intestine. At the mucosal lining of the upper jejunum
Where are the bulk of the dietary sugars absorbed?
Duodenum and upper jejunum
What is maltose made of?
Two glucoses
What is lactose made of?
glucose and galactose
What is sucrose made of?
glucose and fructose
What is the first way glucose gets into the cell?
Through Na+ independent facilitated diffusion transport system. Glucose binds to transported which changes conformation and allows glucose in
Where is GLUT 1 abundant?
erythrocytes and blood brain barrier
Where is GLUT 2 abundant?
Liver and kidneys, pancreatic b cells
Where is GLUT 3 abundant?
neurons
Where is GLUT 4 abundant?
adipose tissue and skeletal muscle
What is the second way glucose gets into cells?
Na+ monosaccharide co transporter system. Requires energy because of concentration gradient. Uses SGLT
Where does the NA+ monosaccharide co transport system occur?
in the epithelial cells of the intestine
Which transporter allows glucose and galactose into the cell?
SGLT
Which transporter allows fructose into the cell?
Fructose
What causes passage of undigested carbs into the large intestine and thus pain and bloating?
Defects in a specific disaccharidase activity
What is metabolism?
The sum of all chemical changes occurring in a cell, tissue, or the body
What are the stages of catabolism?
Hydrolysis of comples molecules, conversion of building blocks to acetyl coa, and oxidation of acetyl coa (oxidative phosphorylation)
What are the steps of glycolysis including enzymes?
Glucose (hexokinase) G6P (PGI) F6P (PFK) F16Bis (Aldolase) G3P+DHAP (TPI) 2G3P (GPD) 1,3 Bis (PGK) 3 Phos (PGM) 2 Phos (Enolase) PEP (PK) Pyruvate
T/F: The glycolytic pathway is only used by the liver cells
False. It is used by all tissues for energy
The irreversible phosphorylation of glucose by enzyme hexokinase traps sugar as what in where?
G6P in cytosol
Heexokinase 1-3 isozymes can be found where?
In most tissues
Hexokinase 4 (Glucokinase) isozyme can be found where?
Liver and pancreas
Glucokinase has a __ Vmax and Km than Hexokinase 1-3
higher
What are hexokinase 1-3 inhibited by and why is that important?
inhibited by G6P, which prevents feedback
What is glucokinase inhibited by?
F6P
What is the most important control point and rate limiting/committed step of glycolysis?
PFK1
What are the 2 major mechanisms for oxidizing NADH?
NADH linked conversion of pyruvate to lactate (anaerobic) and oxidation of NADH via the respiratory chain (aerobic)
Why is arsenic bad?
Because it competes with Pi for GPD, therefore skipping the NADH making step and forming 3 Phos directly. Loss of energy
Where is 2,3 BPG found?
In RBCs where it increases O2 delivery
Enolase is inhibited by what?
Fluoride
Do RBCs have mitochondria?
No. They want room for maximum hemoglobin
The fate of pyruvate depends on what?
The type of cell and availability of oxygen
Is the TCA an aerobic pathway?
Yes. Requires O2 as final electron acceptor
Most of body's catabolic pathways converge at what cycle?
TCA cycle
PDH component enzymes include?
Pyruvate dehydrogenase, dihydrolipoyl transacetylase (E2), dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3)
What are the five coenzymes in the PDH complex?

Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) for pyruvate dehydrogenase
Lipoic acid and CoA for E2
FAD and NAD+ for E3
Arsenic inhibits enzymes that require __ __ as a coenzyme
Lipoic acid
A deficiency in pyruvate dehydrogenase of the PDH complex causes what? Wjhat happens after that?
Congenital lactic acidosis. Pyruvate converted to lactate
a ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex is inhibited by what? What is it activated by?
NADH and succinyl CoA. Activated by Ca 2+
How much ATP is 1 GTP worth and why?
0.75. Because to convert to ATP, it uses one proton
Which is the only enzyme of the TCA that is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane?
Succinate dehydrogenase. It is complex 2 in ETC.
What is another name for fumarase?
fumarate hydratase
What are the three most important regulated enzymes of the TCA?
Citrate synthase, isocitrate dehydrogenase, a ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
In glycolysis, NADH can create either __ ATP through the __ __ shuttle or __ ATP through the __ __ shuttle
2.25 through malate aspartate shuttle or 1.5 through glycerol phosphate shuttle
How much ATP is made through the malate aspartate shuttle total?
31 ATP
How much ATP is made through the glycerol phosphate shuttle total?
Approximately 90% of gluconeogenesis occurs here during an overnight fast
Liver
10% of gluconeogenesis occurs here during an overnight fast
Kidneys
during prolonged fasting, 40% of glucose production occurs here
Kidneys
What are the three substrates for gluconeogenesis?
Glycerol, lactate, and amino acids
Glycerol is released during __ __ __ in adipose tissue and delivered to the __
hydrolysis of TAGs, liver
This substrate can participate in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis
DHAP
Adipocytes lack this
Glycerol kinase
Explain the Cori cycle

pyruvate is turned into lactate in the muscle by lactate dehydrogenase, which is sent to the liver, where it is turned back into pyruvate by lactate dehydrogenase. The pyruvate turns into G6P and then into glucose in the liver and sent back into the skeletal muscle
The major source of glucose during a fast is what?
AAs derived from hydrolysis of tissue protein
Glucogenic AAs yield what when catabolized?
pyruvate or one of the intermediates of the TCA cycle
Which two amino acids can be converted to OOA?
Aspartate and asparagine
Which five AAs can be converted to pyruvate?
Alanine, serine, glycine, cysteine, and threonine
What are the three irreversible reactions of gluconeogenesis
Synthesis of PEP from pyruvate, synthesis of F6P from F16B, and synthesis of glucose from G6P
Where does pyruvate carboxylase occur?
In mito
Where does PEP carboxylase occur?
Cytosol
What does OOA have to be converted into in order to get out of mito?
Malate. Then it is converted back to OOA
Where is glucose 6 phosphatase found?
Liver and kidney only
What are three ways that gluconeogenesis is regulated?
substrate availability, allosteric effectors, and hormones such as glucagon, which stimulates it
Blood glucose is obtained from what 3 sources?
diet, gluconeogenesis, and glycogen degradation
The main stores of glycogen in the body are found in?
Liver and skeletal muscle
What is the function of liver glycogen?
To maintain the balance of blood glucose concentration especially during a fast
What is the function of muscle glycogen?
Serves as a fuel reserve for synthesis of ATP during muscle contraction
Glycogen is a __ chain polysaccharide made exclusively from __ __ __
branched, alpha D glucose
The primary glycosidic bond is an __ linkage
Muscle glycogen is or is not affected during short periods of fasting?
Is not. Only during prolonged fasting (weeks) is muscle glygen level affected
When is glycogen synthesized?
During a well fed state
Where does glycogenesis occur?
In the cytosol. Requires ATP
A deficiency in G6P causes glycogen storage disease type 1a also known as what? What happens?
Von Gierke Disease. Inability of liver to provide free glucose to the body during a fast
Glucagon stimulates what?
Glycogenolysis
Epinephrine stimulates what?
Glycogenolysis
Insulin stimulates what?
Glycogenesis
Phosphorylation of glycogen synthase a leads to what?
conversion to inactive b form
The conversion of glycogen synthase a to the b form is catalyzed by what?
Protein kinases regulated by cAMP
Glycogen synthase b can be reconverted to the a form by what?
protein phosphatase 1. Removes phosphate groups
What is a major source of fructose?
Sucrose
Major source of galactose is?
Lactose
The pentose phosphate pathway is used to generate __ power
Reducing
What is the entry point of the pentose phosphate pathway and what does it generate?
G6P. Generates NADPH and non hexose sugars
Where does the pentose phosphate pathway redominate?
in biosynthetic tissues and erythrocytes
Defects in the pentose phosphate pathway has effects on what?
erythrocytes
Where does the pentose phosphate pathway occur?
cytosol.
What are two key enzymes in the pentose phosphate pathway?
G6P dehydrogenase, 6phosphogluconate dehydrogenase
What are the functions of NADPH?

Reductive biosynthesis (FA synthesis), reduction of hydrogen peroxide (to form reduced glutathione), producing reducing equivalents required by cytochrome P450 monooxygenase system, and maintaining hemoglobin in its reduced form and protecting against hemolysis
Reduced glutathione (GSH) does what?
Works as an antioxidant to convert hydrogen peroxide to water
What are GAGs?
Very negatively charged, long unbranched polysaccharide. Important structural unit of ECM
Lipids produce how much energy?
9kcal/mol
Lipids are __ organic molecules
hydrophobic
Digestion of lipids begins where? and by what?
stomach, catalyzed by lipase
Lipase is a __ __ enzyme
Acid stable
What are the primary targets of lipase?
TAGs
Emulsification of dietary lipid in the small intestine occurs where?
in the duodenum
Emulsificaiton of lipid increases what? And are carried out by what?
Increases SA and carried out by bile salts
What are the steps of lipid breakdown?
Break up, surround with bile salts, break down with lipase
Pancreatic enzymes degrade what?
TAG, Cholesterol esters, and phospholipids
What kind of pancreatic enzyme degrades TAGs?
pancreatic lipase
What kind of pancreatic enzyme degrades cholesterol esters?
Cholesterol esterase
What kind of pancreatic enzyme degrades phospholipids?
Phospholipase A2 and lysophospholipase
TAGs are too large to be taken up efficiently by the mucosal cells of what?
intestinal villi
Pancreatic lipase preferentially removes FAs at which carbons?
C1 and C3
Most dietary cholesterol is present in what form?
Free form (nonesterified)
Cholesteryl esterase hydrolyzes cholesterol esters to what?
Choelsterol and free FAs
Cholesteryl esterase activity is greatly increased in presence of what?
bile salts
Phospholipase A2 removes FA from __ leaving a lysophospholipid
C2
Lysophospholipase removes FA at __ leaving a glycerophosphoryl base
C1
Hormonal control of lipid digestion in the small intestine is done by what two enzymes?
Cholecystokinin and secretin
What cells release cholecystokinin and secretin?
Gut endocrine cells
Cholescystokinin increases what? Which causes what?
gastric motility, increasing secretion of bile and pancreatic enzymes
Lipids along with bile salts and fat soluble vitamins form what?
mixed micelles
What are mixed micelles?
Disk shaped clusters of amphipathic lipids that come together with their hydrophobic groups on the inside and hydrophilic groups on outside
Primary site of lipid absorption is?
brush border membrane of enterocytes
Lipids absorbed by enterocytes are resynthesized to what?
complex lipids in ER
In a chylomicron, the inside is filled with what and the outside with what?
inside is TAG and cholesterol. Outside is phospholipids
Where does the chylomicron travel to?
lymphatic system, then blood
Lipid malabsorption can result in?
steatorrhea (lipid in feces)
Newly resynthesized TAGs and cholesterol esters are very __ and aggregate in an aquesous environment
hydrophobic
What are chylomicrons?
Lipid droplets that package newly resynthesized TAGs and cholesterol esters
Chylomicrons are surrounded by?
phospholipids, unesterified cholesterol, and apolipoprotein
The chylomicrons surounded by phospholipids, unesterified cholesterol, and apolipoprotein __ the solubility of droplet particle
Increases
In the secretion of lipids from enterocytes, particles are released by __ from enterocytes into the lacteals
exocytosis
What are lacteals?
lymphatic vessels originating in the villi of the small intestine
After chylomicrons enter lymph and then blood, what occurs?
TAGs are drawn off by muscle and fat cells and chylomicron remnants are removed from the blood by liver
Why do chylomicrons not go directly into the blood?
Because the chylomicrons are too large to fi through the tight cells of blood vessels. The lymph is more permeable, so it goes there first.
TAGs contained in chylomicrons are broken down primarily in cap beds of __ __ and __ __ by what?
Skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. Lipoprotein lipase
FAs are directly taken up by __ __ and __
muscle cells and adipocytes
This lipid travels in blood until taken up by cells, produces energy in some cells, and stored as TAGs in some cells
FAs
Remaining chylomicron components after TAGs are broken down are
Taken up by liver and hydrolyzed to their parts and some are recylced
FAs exist in different forms in the body. What are these forms?
Free FAs and Fatty acyl esters in TAGs
Free FAs can be __ by many tissues to produce energy. Where?
Oxidized. In liver and muscle
FAs consist of?
Hydorphilic carboxyl group and hydrophobic hydrocarbon chain. They are amphipathic
The alpha carbon in a FA is?
Carbon 2
What is another name for breakdown of FAs?
beta oxidation
More than 90% of FAs found in plasma are in form of?
FA esters
Unesterified (free) FAs are transported in circulation in association with?
Albumin (water soluble)
More than 90% of the FAs found in plasma are in the form of?
FA esters (TAG, cholesteryl esters, phospholipids) contained in circulating lipoprotein particles
Unesterified/free FAs are transported in circulation in association with what?
albumin (water soluble)
FAs are numbered from which end?
Carboxylic end
FAs occur mostly in what molecule?
TAGs
FA chains can be in two forms. What are those two forms and which is dominant?
Cis and trans. Cis is dominant due to the need for inflexible kinks in the chain to be liquid at room temp
Double bonds in FAs are always spaced at what intervals?
3 carbon intervals
Which carbon is carbon number 1?
The carboxyl carbon
How many carbons:double bonds does arachidonic acid have?
What is an example of an omega 3 FA?
a linoleic acid
What is an example of an omega 6 FA?
linoleic acid
What are the first four FAs, the 16 carbon FA, and the essential FAs?
Formic acid, Acetic acid, propionic acid, butryic acid, palmitic acid, linoleic acid, a linoleic acid
A large portion of FAs used by the body is supplied by?
The diet
Carbs and proteins obtained from the diet in excess are converted to FAs stored as?
TAGs
In adults, FA synthesis occurs where?
Liver (main), lactating mammary glands, adipose tissue (lesser extent)
FA synthesis occurs where?
Cytosol
FA synthesis incorporates carbons from what? Using what?
Acetyl CoA. Using ATP or NADPH
FAs are synthesized by repetitive addition of __ carbon units
Acetyl CoA is combined with oxaloacetate in the mitochondria to convert to what so that it can cross the membrane for FA synthesis?
Citrate
In FA synthesis, what happens to the citrate after it crosses the membrane into cytosol?
It converts back to OOA and actetyl CoA
For FA synthesis, the reconversion of citrate to OOA and acetyl CoA is done by what enzyme?
ATP-citrate lyase
What enzyme is responsible for FA synthesis?
FA synthase
In the step in which Acetyl CoA is attached to a FA to make acetyl-ACP, what enzyme catalyzes this reaction?
Transacylase
In the conversion of acetyl coa into malonyl coa, what is the enzyme that catalyzes the reaction?
Acetyl coa carboxylase
This is a multifunctional enzyme in FA synthesis, with separate catalytic domains present in each FAS monomer
FA synthase
What is the largest FA that FAS can handle?
Palmitate (16C)
After FA synthase activity, palmitate can be further elongated by 2 cabon units at which organelle?
Smooth ER
What is the 2 carbon donor for the elongation of palmitic acid in the smooth ER? What supplies the elctrons?
malonyl CoA. NADPH
These enzymes also present in SER are responsible for desaturating long-chain fatty acids. What kind of double bonds do they add?
Desaturases. Cis double bonds
The first double bond added in the SER typically inserts between which carbons?
9 and 10
Mammals cannot introduce a double bond beyond what carbon?
carbon 9
Humans have which desaturases?
C9,6,5,4 desaturases
How do humans get double bonds beyond carbon 10?
By eating them
If an acylglycerol is solid at room temp, it is called __, and if it is liquid at room temp, it is called __
Fat, oil
In TAGs, what type of carbons are carbon 1? 2? 3?
1 is saturated, 2 is unsaturated, and 3 can be either one
TAGs coalesce within what to form oily dropets that are nearly anhydrous?
adipocytes
What is the major energy reserve in the body?
cytosolic lipid droplets consisting of TAGs in adipocytes
What is the initial acceptor of FAs during TAG synthesis?
Glycerol phosphate
Which organs allow for lucose to be converted to glycerol phosphate?
Liver and adipose tissue
What is the enzyme that converts DHAP into glycerol phosphate? Where does it get energy?
Glycerol-P dehydrogenase. NADH
How are FAs activated?
By being attached to CoA
What enzymes catalyze the reaction of FAs being attached to CoAs?
fatty acyl CoA synthetases (thiokinases)
What do you need to make TAGs?
fatty acyl CoAs and glycerol phosphate
In adipose tissue, TAGs are stored as what?
Nearly anhydrous fat droplets in cytosol of cells
TAGs are only stored in low amounts in this organ
Liver
Complete oxidation of FAs results in what molecules?
CO2 and H2O
The hydrolytic release of FAs and glycerol from the TAG form requires what enzyme?
hormone-sensitive lipase
Hormone-sensitive lipase removes FAs from which carbon?
Carbon 1 and/or carbon 3.
What enzymes takes FAs out of circulation and which one puts them in circulation?
Lipoprotein lipase takes FAs out of circulation (synthesis) and hormone-sensitive lipase puts them into circulation (breakdown)
Where does b oxidation occur?
In the mitochondria
What occurs during b oxidation? What is produced?
two carbon fragments are removed from carboxyl end of fatty acyl CoA. Acetyl CoA, NADH, and FADH2 are produced
FAs shorter than how many carbons are able to cross the mitochondrial membrane without carnitine?
If there are an uneven number of C's in a FA, what happens?
The final 3 carbons (propionyl coa) are metabolized to succinyl coa and enters Kreb cycle
Which type of FA provides less energy when broken down?
unsaturated, because less highly reduced. Needs additional enzymes to break down
Very long chain FAs (22 C's or greater) undergo b oxidation in what?
Peroxisomes
An alternate fuel for cells other than FAs are?
Ketone bodies
Ketone bodies are created where? converting what to what?
Liver mitochondria. acetyl coa from FA oxidation
Ketone body synthesis is the result of an excess of what?
acetyl coa
What are the major ketone bodies?
acetoacetate, 3 hydroxybutyrate, and acetone
What is the name of the process of ketone body synthesis in the liver?
ketosis
What is ketonemia?
The rate of formation of ketone bodies is greater than the rate of their use. Levels in blood rise
What is ketouria?
Too much ketone bodies in urine
Ketonemia and ktouria are seen in what disease?
Type one diabetes
A symptom of diabetic ketoacidosis is?
Fruity breath (acetone)
What are some popular phospholipid alcohols?
serine, ethanolamine, and choline
Phospholipids either have what or what as a backbone?
glycerol or sphingosine
all glycerophospholipids are derivatives of what?
phosphatidic acid
Which glycerophospholipid is the simplest?
phosphatidic acid
Sphingomyelin is important for what?
myelin of nerve fibers
What is a ceramide?
A long chain fatty acid attached to the amino group of sphingosine
Where are most phospholipids synthesized?
In the SER
What are some fates of phopholipids?
After SER, transport to Golgi and then to membranes of organelles of plama membrane, or secreted from cell by exocytosis
What are the most abundant phospholipids in eukaryotic cells?
phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylcholine
What hydrolyzes phosphodiester bonds in phosphoglycerides?
phospholipases
Which phospholipase is most important and why?
Phospholipase C, because it cleaves a phosphate group
What are sphingomyelin degraded by?
sphingomyelinase
What is Niemann-Pick disease?
Sphingomyelinase deficiency, so liver and spleen enlared with lipids, severe mental retardation
This lipid contains both carbs and lipids
Glycolipids
What is a difference between glycosphingolipid and a sphingomyelin?
the head of glycosphingolipids are sugars
glycolipids are primarily found where?
In nerve tissue
Glycolipids have this property
Antigenic. The carb portion is antigenic
The simplest glycosphingolipids are called what? They contain a molecule of what?
cerebrosides. Galactose or glucose
What type of glycolipids are acidic? What provides this property?
Gangliosides. Negatively charged at physiological pH. N-acetylneuraminic acid or sulfate groups
enzymes involved in glycosphingolipid synthesis are called what?
glycosyl transferases
Synthesis of glycosphingolipids occurs primarily where?
Golgi
What accomplishes gangliosidosis?
b galactosidase
What cleaves NANA?
Neuraminidase
prostaglandins, thromboxanes, and leukotrienes are known as?
eicosanoids
eicosanoids evoke what response?
inflammatory and hypersensitivity
Eicosanoids are derived from what?
arachidonic acid or EPA
precursor of prostaglandins and thromboxanes are?
linoleic acid
First step in synthesis of prostaglandins is what?
oxidative cyclization of free arachidonic acid to yield PGH2 by enzymes COX1 and 2
Prostaglandin synthesis is inhibited by what?
cortisol and aspirin
What inhibits COX enzymes?
NSAIDS
What are leukotrienes?
mediators of allergeic response and inflammation
Leukotrienes are synthesized from AA by what?
lipoxygenases
What are the functions of steroids?
Fluidity of membrane, precursor to bile acids, steroid hormones, and vit D
What organ plays central role in cholesterol regulation?
Liver
In general, cholesterol will make the membrane?
More rigid
What molecule is synthesized by virtually all tissues in humans? Which organs contribute the most?
Cholesterol. Liver, intestine, adrenal cortex, sex organs
What are the steps of cholesterol synthesis?
Acetyl coa to HMG-CoA, HMG coa to squalene, squalene to cholesterol
What kind of drugs inhibit HMG coa?
Statin drugs
Before bile acids leave the liver, they are conjugated to what?
Glycine or taurine
yellow-green bile is produced by what and stored by what?
hepatocytes. gall bladder
95% of bile salts secreted into intestine are reabsorbed in what?
small intestine
what are lipoproteins?
Spherical macromolecular complexes of lipids
LDLs transport cholesterol to where?
to arteries
